items.title: Is it lights out for overnight flights at Montreal’s Trudeau airport?
items.summary_auto: Aéroports de Montréal is proposing to ban planes from taking off and landing at the airport between 1 a.m. and 6 a.m. in an effort to curb the noise that has been keeping some nearby residents up at night.

items.title: Vince Zampella, video game pioneer behind Call of Duty, dead at 55
items.summary_auto: Vince Zampella, one of the creators behind some of the world's best-selling video games, has died at 55. He helped create the Call of Duty franchise, which has sold more than half a billion games.

items.title: Nicki Minaj says Trump, Vance are 'role models' for young men at Turning Point USA event
items.summary_auto:
Rapper Nicki Minaj on Sunday made a surprise appearance at a gathering of conservatives in Arizona that was memorializing late
activist Charlie Kirk, and used her time on stage to praise U.S. President Donald Trump and Vice-President JD Vance, calling them
"role models" for young men.

items.title: 6 British men charged with more than 60 sexual assault offences against same woman
items.summary_auto: Six British men, including a woman's former husband, were charged with more than 60 sexual offences against her over 13 years, U.K. prosecutors said on Monday.

items.title: Barry Manilow announces surgery for early-stage cancer and postpones January concerts
items.summary_auto: Singer Barry Manilow announced he will be undergoing surgery in late December to remove a cancerous spot on his lung. He announced his January concerts will be postponed to February.

items.title: Scientist says we’ve got whale song all wrong
items.summary_auto: In a new book called Why Whales Sing, Eduardo Mercado details his life's work to try and understand what whale songs are all about.

items.title: Advocates push to legalize the sale of raw milk
items.summary_auto: Selling unpasteurized milk has been illegal in Canada since 1991, due to its high risk of carrying potentially deadly bacteria. But advocates argue there’s still demand for the product, with some Alberta municipalities lobbying the federal government to make sales legal.

items.title: Banksy unveils new art depicting stargazing figures in London
items.summary_auto: Street artist Banksy appeared to confirm via his Instagram account on Monday that a new mural in London, depicting two children lying down and pointing up at the sky, is his latest work.

items.title: Quebec ERs are overflowing before flu season hits its peak
items.summary_auto: Before the height of flu season, Quebec emergency rooms are overflowing in several regions, including the greater Montreal area, Centre-du-Québec and the Capitale-Nationale.

items.title: Ottawa offers over $35.5B for First Nations child welfare reform
Canada Post and union representing workers reach tentative agreement, agree not to strike
items.summary_auto: The tentative agreement comes after the two parties first agreed to a deal in principle last month. Today's agreement finalizes "contractual language" and will prevent either side from locking workers out or striking, ahead of the busy holiday season.

items.title: International Swimming League targets 2026 relaunch after COVID, war disruptions
items.summary_auto: The International Swimming League plans to relaunch as soon as 2026 after a three-year hiatus, betting a reshaped commercial model, stable backing and momentum from the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics can sustain a global, team-based competition in one of the Games' marquee sports.

items.title: Ontario senior's friends found gift cards given to them were empty. Consumers warned of 'gift card draining'
items.summary_auto: Mark Duguay of Windsor says $275 worth of Tim Hortons cards he bought for friends couldn't be redeemed because they'd already been drained of funds. The CEO of the Better Business Bureau for Western Ontario says it's not an uncommon issue due to scams that may include bar code tampering.

items.title: RCMP charge 2 men for allegedly using women to smuggle cannabis from Toronto to Nigeria
items.summary_auto: The RCMP arrested two men who allegedly used a classified ads website to recruit women to smuggle cannabis out of Canada to Nigeria via the country’s biggest airport.

items.title: IDF says it shot teen in West Bank after hurling brick at soldiers. Video appears to contradict that
items.summary_auto: The Israeli military said it was reviewing an incident in the occupied West Bank in which soldiers shot dead a 16-year-old Palestinian who they said had thrown a brick at them, after CCTV footage appeared to show he was not doing so when shot.

items.title: Canadian among fired workers from Grand Theft Auto studio says they just want their jobs back
items.summary_auto: The firing of several employees at the makers of the Grand Theft Auto video games came as a complete surprise, according to one of the Canadian workers who was let go this past fall.

items.title: Four people hospitalized related to Pizza Pops recall, CFIA says
items.summary_auto: The recall extends to a number of kinds of Pizza Pops of various packaging sizes with best-before dates for mid-June 2026. The Canadian Food Inspection Agency says the contaminated food may not look or smell spoiled, but can still make you sick.

items.title: Stranded passengers 'exhausted,’ 'annoyed' over four days of Wabush flight cancellations
items.summary_auto: Icy weather conditions have forced the closure of the Wabush Airport's runway for four days, leaving hundreds of passengers waiting for new flights. While PAL Airlines says they have offered accommodation, one stranded passenger says he has been offered no help.

items.title: Mayor invites Hallmark to film in Alberta town residents call a real life romance set
items.summary_auto: If you’re looking for love – Sylvan Lake might just be the place, with aesthetics and a community that rivals any romance film script. But now the town is gunning to actually be the backdrop for one.

items.title: CBS pulls 60 Minutes report on El Salvador's CECOT prison hours before airtime
items.summary_auto: CBS News pulled a 60 Minutes report on El Salvador's CECOT prison just hours before its scheduled Sunday broadcast, saying it would air at a future time.

items.title: National trends point to Canadians spending less this holiday season
items.summary_auto: As people look to save money any way they can, those who represent businesses in the retail sector hope the "shop local" campaign results in a solid bottom line for retailers during the holiday shopping period.

items.title: Russian general killed in car bomb in Moscow, investigators say
items.summary_auto: A car bomb killed a Russian general on Monday, the third such killing of a senior military officer in just over a year. Investigators said Ukraine may be behind the attack.

items.title: Ottawa cobbler on 25 years of fixes — and the sidewalk staple 'that will kill your shoes'
items.summary_auto: Muhamad Merhi has operated a shoe repair stand inside the federal government's C.D. Howe Building for a quarter-century. 'I don't think I would have survived outside,' he says.

items.title: New study finds AI chatbots can influence some Canadians to change their vote
items.summary_auto: Talking with an AI chatbot can successfully convince people to change their votes and could affect the outcome of future elections, according to a newly published study. However, Canada has few, if any, rules to govern how artificial intelligence is used in future elections.

items.title: 'It's like Groundhog Day': Waiting decades for justice in India's overburdened court system
items.summary_auto: India's archaic judicial system and its backlog of millions of cases leave those seeking justice, along with many lawyers and judges, with a sense of hopelessness.

items.title: Who benefits from the Arctic economic and security corridor? It depends who you ask
items.summary_auto: Many northern leaders have been touting the Arctic economic and security corridor as a 'nation-building' project that will bring economic benefits to the two territories it straddles, but some community leaders are split on how much good will come out of it.
